content.title: UNPACKING THE CONCEPT OF A JUST ENERGY TRANSITION
content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

The concept of a just energy transition is multifaceted, with no single, universally accepted definition. Its interpretation varies across different social, economic, and political contexts. At its core, a just transition seeks to balance the urgent need to reduce carbon emissions with the responsibility to ensure that both the benefits and burdens of this shift are distributed equitably. This lesson will explore how a just transition goes beyond technical solutions and policy frameworks—it is about addressing deep-rooted socio-economic disparities, fostering participatory governance, and empowering all stakeholders as active agents of change. It emphasizes equal access to the benefits of the transition, such as clean energy and energy security, ensuring they are not limited to certain regions or privileged groups but are shared across all of society.

content.title: Part 1: Origins of the Just Transition Concept

content.text: Part 1 Overview

The concept of a just transition originated in the 1980s through advocacy by global trade unions, which sought to safeguard workers displaced by environmental regulations, exemplified by initiatives like the "Superfund for Workers" to support fossil fuel industry employees. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO, 2024) , a just transition involves greening the economy in a manner that maximizes fairness and inclusivity for all stakeholders. Equity must be integrated into policies and strategies, with inclusivity serving as a guiding principle to engage every community, worker, and social group in decision-making processes (Sovacool et al., 2017). This approach aims to generate decent work opportunities, leaving no one behind in the process.

However, contemporary scholarship has expanded this framework beyond labor-centric concerns to integrate climate, energy, and environmental justice, ensuring inclusivity for historically marginalized groups, Indigenous communities, and regions disproportionately impacted by both climate change and transition policies. Raphael Heffron, a leading scholar in this field, argues that a just transition requires a "triumvirate of justice tenets": distributional equity (fair resource allocation), procedural fairness (inclusive decision-making), and restorative measures (addressing historical harms) (Heffron & de Fontenelle, 2024). This approach moves beyond the ILO’s traditional focus on labor rights to emphasize multisectoral equity, aligning with the Paris Agreement’s call for holistic climate action. For instance, Heffron’s work highlights the need to repurpose fossil fuel infrastructure while ensuring communities dependent on extractive industries receive retraining, renewable job opportunities, and participatory governance. Critically, the transition must reconcile global climate goals with localized realities. Poorly contextualized policies risk exacerbating inequalities, particularly in the Global South, where energy demand grows alongside entrenched poverty (McCauley & Heffron, 2018). Effective strategies involve decentralizing decision-making to engage local stakeholders—governments, businesses, Indigenous leaders, and civil society—in designing context-specific solutions, such as community-owned solar microgrids or gender-inclusive green job programs. By prioritizing restorative justice and participatory frameworks, the transition can transcend tokenistic inclusivity, ensuring environmental sustainability and socio-economic equity are mutually reinforcing.

Implicit in the discourse Of just transition is the acknowledgment that transitions can be disruptive, underscoring the necessity for intentional efforts to facilitate a smooth and equitable transition for all involved parties.

content.title: Part 2: Environmental, Climate and Energy Justice

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Beyond its labour-oriented origins, a just transition is deeply rooted in the broader frameworks of environmental, climate, and energy justice. Research increasingly highlights diverse interpretations of a just transition (Wang & Lo, 2021), but at its core, the term ‘just’ refers to addressing and rectifying the injustices experienced by communities that have long been marginalized by the existing energy system (Williams & Doyon, 2019).

Environmental Justice is equally crucial in this context. Traditionally, it has focused on ensuring fair treatment and involvement of people from all backgrounds in shaping environmental policies and laws. However, given today's global challenges, especially climate change, the scope of environmental justice has broadened to emphasize the protection of human rights. Climate change disproportionately affects women, children, and marginalized communities, making environmental justice essential to addressing these deepening inequalities.
Environmental justice seeks fairness in how environmental benefits and burdens are distributed, emphasizing:

Intragenerational equity ensures fair access to resources and opportunities within the current generation, while intergenerational equity focuses on preserving resources and environmental health for future generations. Distributive justice, ensuring fair distribution of environmental benefits and burdens, preventing further marginalization of vulnerable groups. Corrective justice, which involves compensation, access to justice, and legal empowerment for communities harmed by environmental damage. Procedural fairness, requiring open, transparent, and inclusive decision-making processes.
Additionally, environmental justice includes the emerging ideas of ecological justice, recognizing the environment itself has rights, and the need for sustainability as a foundation for justice.

Developing countries, which contribute the least to climate change, suffer the most from its impacts. Groups such as children, the elderly, Indigenous peoples, refugees, and economically disadvantaged individuals are often the hardest hit, with fewer resources to adapt. Women and girls, in particular, face additional barriers, such as limited access to resources and remedies. Climate change is already causing widespread losses in livelihoods, housing, and food security, while also fueling migration and conflicts over natural resources.

Climate Justice, therefore, frames climate change as an ethical and political issue, stressing the need to ensure that the most vulnerable communities are not disproportionately impacted by climate policies and actions.
Key components of climate justice include:

Equity: Fair distribution of the benefits and burdens of climate change, both within and between countries, as well as across different generations. Human Rights: Protecting the rights of those most affected by climate change, including indigenous peoples and low-income communities. Participation: Ensuring affected communities are involved in shaping climate policies. Accountability: Holding those responsible for climate change accountable for their actions and contributions to solutions.
UNPACKING THE CONCEPT OF A JUST ENERGY TRANSITION

The concept of Energy Justice has gained prominence in the context of the global shift to renewable energy. It addresses the need to integrate equity and social justice into energy policy debates. Communities most impacted by pollution and climate change, especially those historically underserved and marginalised by racial, economic, and social inequality, call for energy policies that reflect their unique experiences of harm (IEJ, 2019.)
Energy justice builds on the principles of environmental and climate justice and should not be viewed separately.

Energy Justice focuses on the fair distribution of the benefits and burdens associated with energy production, distribution, and consumption. It emphasizes tackling inequalities in energy access, affordability, and environmental impact, with a special focus on vulnerable and marginalized groups.
Key components of energy justice include:
Distributional justice

In energy justice, it focuses on the fair allocation of both benefits and burdens of energy resources across communities. It considers the placement of energy projects, such as power plants or renewable installations, and examines who bears the costs associated with energy access and infrastructure changes. It also considers equitable access to energy services and, from a consumption perspective, issues like fuel poverty as the uneven distribution of burdens related to affordable energy access.
Procedural justice

It ensures inclusive and transparent participation in energy-related decisions, determining who has a say in energy projects and policy processes. This is crucial in energy planning, where affected communities should have input on projects that influence their energy access and costs. It also applies to decisions across the entire energy value chain that directly or indirectly impact local communities, including resource extraction, transmission network installations, and generation plant construction.
Recognition justice

It ensures that the unique needs and values of diverse groups, especially those often marginalized, are respected within energy systems. It requires active dialogue and understanding of different worldviews and cosmologies. For instance, in the context of renewable energy projects, this might involve understanding an Indigenous community's relationship with natural elements, such as the Wayúu people's connection to the winds in La Guajira. Recognition justice also applies to energy access policies, acknowledging that elderly or chronically ill people may have distinct energy needs, which could necessitate differentiated tariffs.
Restorative justice

Within energy justice, restorative justice seeks to address past injustices in energy policies that have disadvantaged specific communities. This may involve compensatory measures or targeted investments to correct historic disparities in energy access or to mitigate the impacts of specific energy projects on their lands.
While climate, environmental, and energy justice share similar components, their implications differ by context. Understanding each movement’s core claims is key to appreciating these differences.

Energy justice frameworks center on four key principles—procedural justice, distributional justice, justice as recognition, and restorative justice—which together emphasize that a sustainable energy transition must be both environmentally responsible and socially equitable. According to Jenkins et al. (2016), these principles ensure that decision-making processes are fair and inclusive, that the benefits and burdens of energy transitions are shared equitably, that diverse community identities are acknowledged and respected, and that past environmental injustices are actively addressed and remedied.

content.title: Part 3: Global Principles, Local Solutions

content.text: UNPACKING THE CONCEPT OF A JUST ENERGY TRANSITION

A just energy transition necessitates context-sensitive investments in domestic and localized measures, particularly where renewable resources are viable, complemented by regional cooperation to address uneven resource distribution. Without such tailored strategies, there is a risk of poorly designed solutions. These efforts must adhere to justice-based frameworks, such as the eight principles established by the UNDP-led Alliance for Just Energy Transformation (AJET), ensuring equity and inclusivity guide implementation.

The 8 principles of a Just Energy Transformation aim to outline a shared understanding towards successful implementation of Just Transition policies worldwide, even as the details of the transitions differ at national scales.

Recognizing the interconnected nature of social, economic, and environmental factors is crucial. The urgency of addressing climate change is intertwined with the need for socio-economic development and environmental preservation. Hence, a holistic approach is essential to navigate the complex challenges associated with the transition. Global energy challenges extend beyond the energy sector, impacting various policy areas and exacerbating societal fragility. In this context, achieving a just energy transition through effective, accountable, and inclusive energy governance is crucial for addressing immediate national development priorities, environmental concerns, safeguarding human rights, and preserving social stability.

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: The "just transition" framework ensures fairness, equity, and inclusivity in the shift to sustainable energy systems.
takeaways.description: Rooted in principles of environmental, climate, and energy justice, the concept has evolved from protecting workers to addressing historical injustices faced by marginalized communities, ensuring no one is left behind in the energy transition.

takeaways.title: A localized vision is essential for a just transition, addressing the intersection of climate crises and systemic inequalities.
takeaways.description: Recognizing the unique challenges and historical contexts of each region, a just transition must be tailored to local needs, fostering equitable solutions that align with global sustainability goals while addressing escalating inequalities.

takeaways.title: The 8 principles of Just Energy Transformation provide a framework for implementing just transition policies.
takeaways.description: Developed by AJET, these principles offer a shared foundation for just transition strategies, adaptable to national and local contexts, ensuring cohesive and inclusive approaches to energy system transformation worldwide.
